categories.title: Daily Rhythm SOS
categories.description: Repair routines quickly when schedules wobble or confidence dips.

items.title: Potty Accident Reset
items.summary: Reboot the bathroom plan after surprise puddles indoors.
items.doNow: Clip the leash, walk directly to the original potty zone, and reward with a rapid treat trio the instant the puppy finishes outside.
items.prevent: Log wake, meal, and play times for three days so you can pre-empt breaks 10 minutes earlier than the last accident.
items.trainerTip: Treat potty breaks like a mini mission—no sniff walks until after success so the cue sequence stays crystal clear.

items.title: Crate Protest Calmer
items.summary: Lower the volume when puppies bark or dig at the crate door.
items.doNow: Load a lick mat, cover three crate sides, and sit nearby breathing slowly until your puppy settles, then release before they escalate again.
items.prevent: Schedule crate reps after potty + play so tired bodies are ready to nap, and stick with short 2–3 minute sessions before stretching time.
items.trainerTip: Alternate crate locations each day—mobility keeps puppies from pairing the crate with only bedtime separation.

items.title: Alone-Time Tears
items.summary: Support puppies who cry the moment you step out of sight.
items.doNow: Give a stuffed chew, start a one-minute timer, and return with a calm treat drop before the first whine crests so confidence stays intact.
items.prevent: Mix in decoy departures—grab keys, sit back down—to break the pattern that every cue predicts leaving.
items.trainerTip: Track the exact second your puppy vocalizes so you can build a predictable ladder of easy wins before extending duration.

categories.title: Behavior Resets
categories.description: Quick triage plans for the most common puppy SOS moments.

items.title: Evening Biting Spikes
items.summary: Redirect shark teeth during the pre-bed zoomie hour.
items.doNow: Swap hands for a tug toy immediately, cue trade after 10 seconds, and end the game for a 20-second calm break if teeth land on skin twice.
items.prevent: Schedule a sniffy walk + scatter feed before the usual witching hour so arousal is already on its way down.
items.trainerTip: Narrate "take your toy" every time you present it—consistent language speeds up redirected grabs.

items.title: Doorbell Bark Plan
items.summary: Lower alert barking when new sounds happen.
items.doNow: Scatter 10 treats on a mat as soon as barking starts, breathe with your puppy, then cue an easy sit before opening the door again.
items.prevent: Run two fake doorbell sessions daily pairing the chime with treat scatters so the bell predicts snacks, not chaos.
items.trainerTip: Record and replay real household sounds at low volume during meals to keep sub-threshold exposure going.

items.title: Jumping Greetings
items.summary: Teach four-on-the-floor manners when people walk in.
items.doNow: Cue sit on a mat before the helper approaches; if paws lift, have the helper pivot away until the puppy lands back in a sit.
items.prevent: Have visitors toss treats behind the puppy as they enter so spinning to chase replaces leaping straight ahead.
items.trainerTip: Install a hand-target cue and use it as the first request when friends arrive—giving paws a job keeps them grounded.

items.title: Furniture Chew Patrol
items.summary: Offer legal outlets before chair legs become toys.
items.doNow: Leash to you, park on a mat with a tethered chew, and reward every glance back to you for five minutes.
items.prevent: Rotate three textures daily and store chews out of reach so novelty stays high when you present them.
items.trainerTip: Practice leave-it with real household objects on leash walks so disengaging becomes the default response.

categories.title: Focus & Movement
categories.description: Keep brains engaged during training, walks, and multi-pet moments.

items.title: Can't Focus On You
items.summary: Boost engagement when puppies stare at everything except their human.
items.doNow: Play a 30-second name game burst, feeding any head turn toward you, then reset with a toss behind you so they choose to reorient.
items.prevent: Keep sessions to five reps and end before interest dips; sprinkle surprise recall games through the day instead of marathon practices.
items.trainerTip: Track the rooms or yards with the best focus so you can increase difficulty only when your puppy is ready.

items.title: Leash Zoomies
items.summary: Handle pulling and hopping at the end of the leash.
items.doNow: Plant your feet the second the leash tightens, cue touch when your puppy glances back, and feed at your pant seam before moving again.
items.prevent: Run two-minute figure eights indoors before every walk so muscles remember the loose-leash pattern.
items.trainerTip: Pair harness time with sniff walks; if gear predicts freedom, puppies volunteer to gear up calmly.

items.title: Other-Pet Introductions
items.summary: Keep greetings with resident cats or dogs chill and safe.
items.doNow: Gate the puppy, toss treats for looking at the resident pet, then cue an easy sit before releasing pressure.
items.prevent: Give each species escape routes and run scent-swaps before face-to-face time so novelty drops.
items.trainerTip: End while both animals are still relaxed—success is short, sweet exposure, not full play on day one.
